head.title: Fundamental Mechanisms of Reversible Dehydrogenation of Formate on N-Doped Graphene-Supported Pd Nanoparticles | The Journal of Physical Chemistry C

meta.content: Fundamental Mechanisms of Reversible Dehydrogenation of Formate on N-Doped Graphene-Supported Pd Nanoparticles

Reversible formate (HCOO–) dehydrogenation and bicarbonate (HCO3–) hydrogenation would be desirable for the utilization and storage of hydrogen (H2) as an effective energy carrier. Carbon-supported Pd-based nanoparticles demonstrated enormous competitive advantages for these reactions. However, the fundamental mechanisms underlying these reversible reactions have not yet been elucidated. Herein, we report the reaction pathways for reversible reactions on a Pd-based catalyst using density functional theory (DFT) calculations and propose key factors for improving the reaction efficiency. As the first essential step, the difficulty in the conventional DFT modeling, that is simulation of an anion environment caused by HCOO–, was overcome by designing two-sided Pd12 nanoclusters supported on graphene (Pd12NC-G) with extra electrons. Using Pd12NC-G, we demonstrated that the key factor determining the potential limiting steps for the reversible reaction was desorption of hydrogen in HCOO– dehydrogenation (1.24 eV) and HCO3– hydrogenation (1.49 eV). The key factor was the same in Pd12NC-N1G, Pd12NC-N2G, and Pd12NC-N3G (where N1, N2, and N3 represent the number of N atoms doped on carbon). Among these, the Pd12NC-N2G model with the appropriate amount of nitrogen doping showed optimal hydrogen adsorption strength corresponding to the smallest d-band center and spin density values, resulting in the lowest energy barriers for HCOO– dehydrogenation (0.76 eV) and HCO3– hydrogenation (0.96 eV). Based on harmonization between electronic and geometrical properties, we demonstrated that the appropriate level of nitrogen doping can provide the optimal balance between the magnitude of reactivity and the number of sites for improving the efficiency of the reversible reactions.

div.p:
Reversible formate (HCOO
–
) dehydrogenation and bicarbonate (HCO
3
–
) hydrogenation would be desirable for the utilization and storage of hydrogen (H
2
) as an effective energy carrier. Carbon-supported Pd-based nanoparticles demonstrated enormous competitive advantages for these reactions. However, the fundamental mechanisms underlying these reversible reactions have not yet been elucidated. Herein, we report the reaction pathways for reversible reactions on a Pd-based catalyst using density functional theory (DFT) calculations and propose key factors for improving the reaction efficiency. As the first essential step, the difficulty in the conventional DFT modeling, that is simulation of an anion environment caused by HCOO
–
, was overcome by designing two-sided Pd
12
nanoclusters supported on graphene (Pd
12
NC-G) with extra electrons. Using Pd
12
NC-G, we demonstrated that the key factor determining the potential limiting steps for the reversible reaction was desorption of hydrogen in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation (1.24 eV) and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation (1.49 eV). The key factor was the same in Pd
12
NC-N
1
G, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G, and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G (where N
1
, N
2
, and N
3
represent the number of N atoms doped on carbon). Among these, the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G model with the appropriate amount of nitrogen doping showed optimal hydrogen adsorption strength corresponding to the smallest d-band center and spin density values, resulting in the lowest energy barriers for HCOO
–
dehydrogenation (0.76 eV) and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation (0.96 eV). Based on harmonization between electronic and geometrical properties, we demonstrated that the appropriate level of nitrogen doping can provide the optimal balance between the magnitude of reactivity and the number of sites for improving the efficiency of the reversible reactions.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Fossil fuels, which have a long history of use as energy sources, are known to cause serious environmental problems across the globe. Further, with the existing quality of life, there is increased energy consumption, which is one of the important factors responsible for the depletion of fossil fuels.
(1)
Numerous studies have been pursued to identify environmentally friendly energy sources as a replacement for fossil fuels. Hydrogen (H
2
) is a clean source of energy because it reacts with oxygen to produce water without the emission of pollutants such as exhaust gas, unlike the case of conventional fossil fuels and has the ultimate effect in terms of energy storage and transportation.
(2−4)

Because of its extremely low volumetric energy density at atmospheric pressure, hydrogen must be stored in compressed gas or liquid form.
(5−7)
Formic acid (HCOOH), with its high volumetric and gravimetric energy density, has been demonstrated to be a very efficient liquid hydrogen storage medium.
(8−12)
Among the various transition-metal catalysts used for HCOOH decomposition, Pd is reported to be the most suitable and shows the highest H
2
production.
(12−14)
However, a major drawback is the occurrence of two competitive dehydrogenation pathways: (HCOOH → CO
2
+ H
2
) and the undesired dehydration (HCOOH → CO + H
2
O).
(11)
CO produced in the latter case poisons the catalyst surface (e.g., Pt), thereby reducing the reactivity and durability of the catalyst.
(15)

Attempts have been made to tune the structure and composition of the Pd catalysts so that CO formation is suppressed and the selectivity of the catalyst to HCOOH decomposition is enhanced.
(16−20)
A nanocluster (NC) or core–shell catalyst composed of an alloy rather than a single metal shows efficiency for the good decomposition of HCOOH. For example, Ag/Pd NC catalysts completely prevented CO production,
(17)
and carbon-supported Pd catalysts also effectively inhibited CO generation.
(16,18)
Combined catalysts such as Pd–Ag/carbon and Pd–Au/carbon also successfully suppressed the production of CO and improved the dehydrogenation efficiency of HCOOH.
(19)
In addition, dopants played a beneficial role, for example, a nitrogen-doped graphene-supported Pd catalyst successfully suppressed the generation of CO and maximized the generation of H
2
gas.
(20−22)
However, without additional additives for stabilization, HCOOH has a major limitation in direct hydrogenation for H
2
storage.
(23)

Recently, the formate (HCOO
–
) species has attracted much attention as a potential hydrogen storage medium.
(8,15,23−25)
HCOO
–
is comparable to HCOOH in terms of stability and nontoxicity but follows a different reaction pathway for dehydrogenation with suppressed CO generation.
(15,24)
The most prominent advantage of HCOO
–
is that a stable reversible reaction between HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation is possible without additives, unlike HCOOH that requires addition of organic or inorganic matters for optimal dehydrogenation efficiency.
(23)
Additionally, carbon-supported Pd catalysts show high activity, selectivity, and reversibility in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation.
(15,25)
In particular, Pd nanoparticles supported on reduced graphite oxide nanosheets as the catalyst allowed for the abovementioned reversible reaction to occur repeatedly.
(25)
Hence, HCOO
–
shows lesser efficiency for H
2
storage and production than HCOOH, but it is better for long-term utilization. However, because of the lack of in-depth studies, the mechanisms for the HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation have not been well understood. A more detailed analysis is thus essential to understand the fundamental mechanisms underlying the reversibility in the dehydrogenation of HCOO
–
and to develop new materials for enhanced H
2
storage and production.

Therefore, in the current study, we analyzed the mechanism underlying the dehydrogenation and reversible reaction of HCOO
–
on the N-doped graphene-supported Pd nanoparticle catalyst with the aim of identifying the factors that can improve the reaction efficiency. To this end, we first systematized a density functional theory (DFT) calculation supercell model to maximize the effect of the anion environment of HCOO
–
by localizing the additional electron near the surface of the catalyst model. To the best of our knowledge, such a methodology has not been previously reported. The dehydrogenation of HCOO
–
was then simulated in the absence and presence of N dopants in the graphene support of the Pd catalyst. The findings of this study will contribute to a clear understanding and application of hydrogen energy as a next-generation energy source.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP)
(26,27)
with the projector-augmented wave (PAW)
(27,28)
method. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional
(29)
with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to describe the electron exchange correlation functions. An energy cut of 400 eV was applied for the plane-wave basis set, and Brillouin zone integration was performed on a 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack grid
(30)
for all surfaces. The first-order Methfessel–Paxton smearing
(31)
with a value of 0.1 eV was applied.

The Pd
12
NC-graphene (Pd
12
NC-G) system (
Figure
1
) was designed based on a 14.80 × 12.82 × 30.00 Å orthorhombic supercell with periodic boundary conditions. The system consisted of 12 Pd atom NC (Pd
12
NC) anchored at the carbon vacancy sites of mono-vacancy graphene (71 carbon atoms). The Pd
12
NC has a relatively large flat surface unlike the conventional spherelike NC, minimizing the limitation of overestimating the adsorption energy because of the edges of the clusters. Previous studies reported that the M
12
NC (where M = metal atoms) consisting of two atomic triangle layers provided active adsorption sites for reaction with adsorbates
(32)
and that the monovacancy defective graphene enhances the binding properties of the NC
(33)
and the surface reactivity.
(34−36)
The Pd
12
NC was stably anchored with an adsorption energy of −6.22 eV at the monovacancy site, and in particular the relatively thin Pd layers would provide a good environment for observing the N-doping effect in graphene. In addition, among various N-doping configurations on graphene (such as pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic-N doping), the pyridinic-N doping configuration was employed in the Pd
12
NC supported on N-doped graphene (Pd
12
NC-N
x
G, where
x
is the number of nitrogen) because it greatly enhances the reactivity of graphene, as demonstrated by measuring the efficiency of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR).
(37)
Based on this system, the Pd
12
NC-N
x
G was designed by replacing the carbon atoms of graphene with nitrogen atoms.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Top view of Pd
12
NC. (b) Bottom view of Pd
12
NC supported on monovacancy graphene (Pd
12
NC-G). (c) Side view of two-sided Pd
12
NC-G model with additional electrons (an expanded supercell is shown in
Figure S1
). Silver and brown spheres represent Pd and C, respectively. Arrows with e
–
indicate that extra electrons are added to the supercell to mimic the anion environment of HCOO
–
.

div.div:
The supercell had two symmetrical Pd
12
NC-G structures (
Figure
1
c) to mimic the anion environment of HCOO
–
by avoiding electron accumulation at the bottom of the graphene support on addition of extra electrons to the supercell. The vacuum space between the two symmetrical Pd
12
NC-G was more than 15 Å. Details of the effect of the symmetrical supercell are discussed in
Supporting Information
Section S1, and additional views of the supercell are shown in
Figures S1 and S2
.

All atoms of the Pd
12
NC-G and Pd
12
NC-N
x
G systems were fully relaxed and optimized until the convergence criterion for electronic self-consistent iteration was less than 10
–4
eV. The gas-phase molecules were optimized using Brillouin zone integration with only the Γ-point under the same conditions as those used for the surface calculations.

The reaction pathways were analyzed by calculating solvation free energies of the intermediate species in the dehydrogenation of HCOO
–
and hydrogenation of HCO
3
–
. Charge transfer in the Pd
12
NC-G and Pd
12
NC-N
x
G systems was investigated using the charge density difference (CDD) (Δ
n
(
r
)) analysis.
(33,35)
The CDD is calculated as follows
where
n
substrate+adsorbate
(
r
),
n
substrate
(
r
), and
n
adsorbate
(
r
) are the electron charge densities of the Pd
12
NC-G system (or Pd
12
NC-N
x
G system), graphene (or N-doped graphene), and Pd
12
NC, respectively. Detailed calculation data and method for the solvation free energy are shown in
Supporting Information
Section S2.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Previous studies investigating formic acid (HCOOH) dehydrogenation have demonstrated that a HCOO* intermediate (where * represents the state adsorbed on the catalyst surface) is produced.
(11,12,38)
However, it has been reported that formate (HCOO
–
) dehydrogenation is entirely different from the dehydrogenation of HCOO* produced by HCOOH.
(8,15,25)
Because it is impossible to add an extra electron at a certain location in the supercell, the conventional DFT modeling method used for HCOOH dehydrogenation may not be applicable to HCOO
–
. Extra electrons added to a supercell are not localized near the catalyst surface but are scattered widely on the top and bottom of the supercell. To solve this problem, we designed the Pd
12
NC-G system shown in
Figure
1
c (and
Figure S1
) such that the added electrons were mainly distributed on the catalyst surfaces and directly participated in the surface reaction.

Figure
2
a shows the integrated charge density of CDD in the
x
–
y
plane plotted in the direction normal to the surface, indicating charge accumulation on the addition of extra electrons. This figure demonstrates that the added electrons in the one-sided Pd
12
NC-G model (the conventional method) are mainly distributed in the bottom part of the graphene and not on the catalyst surface where HCOO is adsorbed. The extra electrons dispersed at the bottom of the one-sided catalyst system may not contribute to the anion environment for HCOO
–
dehydrogenation on the catalyst surface, implying that the one-sided system might not be appropriate for simulating the anion environment. On the other hand, as shown in
Figure
2
b, a greater number of electrons added to the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G model were distributed on the top surface. Quantitatively, 36.6% of the electrons added to the one-sided Pd
12
NC-G model were located at the bottom part of graphene. In contrast, only 12.2% of the electrons in the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G model were located in the bottom part of graphene, and a large number of electrons were localized on the Pd surface, indicating that the anion environment localizing the electrons on the catalyst surface could be maximized. Therefore, the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G surface model was demonstrated to be more suitable for simulating the anion environment of HCOO
–
than the one-sided model. The electron distribution on the clean two-sided model with additional electrons also showed localization on the top surface, as in the case of HCOO
–
adsorbed on the model. The results of CDD analysis for the clean Pd
12
NC-G surfaces with additional electrons are shown in
Figure S2
.

div.p:
Figure 2. Integrated charge density of CDD in the
x
–
y
plane plotted in the direction normal to the surface in the one-sided (a) and two-sided (b) models with adsorbed HCOO and extra electrons. Dashed areas indicate where the extra electrons are mainly distributed in each system. The Pd
12
NC-G structure is illustrated in
Figure
1
.

div.h3:
3.2. Dehydrogenation Pathway of Formate (HCOO
–
to HCO
3
–
+ H
2
)
div.div:
The HCOO
–
dehydrogenation pathway was analyzed by using the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G surface suitable for the anion environment modeling. An important experimental observation during hydrogen gas formation is that one H originates from H
2
O and the other from HCOO
–
.
(15)
Accordingly, various adsorption configurations of the intermediate species were designed, and their DFT energies were calculated to determine the most stable reaction pathway, as shown in
Figures
3
a and
4
a. As per this pathway, HCOO
–
was dehydrogenated via HCOO* → CO
2
*
+ H* → HCO
3
* + H* → HCO
3
–
(g)
+ H* → HCO
3
–
(g)
+ H
2(g)
[where (g) represents the gas-phase state]. In the first step (step 1 → 2 in
Figure
4
a), HCOO
–
dehydrogenation was initiated as OH was adsorbed on HCOO* to produce H
2
CO
3
*
or H was dissociated from HCOO* to produce CO
2
*
and H*. Note that dissociation of H from HCOO* was energetically more stable than the adsorption of OH dissociated from H
2
O on HCOO
–
. This implied that the formation of CO
2
*
+ H* was more stable than the formation of H
2
CO
3
*
and that one H atom constituting the final product H
2(g)
originated from HCOO
–
(the other H for H
2(g)
was provided from H
2
O); these results agreed well with the experimental observations reported by Koh et al.
(15)

div.p:
Figure 3. Schematic diagram for the reversible dehydrogenation of HCOO
–
and hydrogenation of HCO
3
–
on the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G surface. Blue and red arrows represent HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation, respectively.

Figure 4. Relative solvation free energy diagram for HCOO
–
dehydrogenation on (a) two-sided Pd
12
NC-G with extra electrons for the overall reaction and on (b) one-sided Pd
12
NC-G without extra electrons for reaction step 2 → 3. The black solid line with filled rectangles represents the most stable reaction pathway for HCOO
–
dehydrogenation. The red solid and dotted lines with filled and unfilled rectangles represent the production of CO
2(g)
and H
2(g)
, similar to H
2(g)
production via HCOOH dehydrogenation.

div.div:
The adsorption configuration of HCOO
–
(reaction step 1 in
Figure
3
a) was found to be a highly important factor for the production of HCO
3
*
. The configuration in which the two oxygen atoms of HCOO
–
were adsorbed on the catalyst surface was more energetically stable than that in which one oxygen atom and one hydrogen atom were adsorbed, resulting in the formation of CO
2
*
+ H* in reaction step 2 in
Figure
4
a. The adsorption configuration of HCOO
–
with two oxygens on the surface made the hydrogen atom relatively free over other atoms and created an environment for smooth dissociation, thereby playing an important role in the formation of energetically stable CO
2
*
. On the other hand, in the adsorption configuration with oxygen and hydrogen atoms, dissociation of the hydrogen atom from HCOO
–
was difficult because it strongly interacted with the Pd surface, thus being a major obstacle to the formation of CO
2
*
. In addition, the electronegativities of O, H, and Pd (3.44, 2.20, and 2.20 on the Pauling scale, respectively) supported the results that the configuration of HCOO
–
with two adsorbed oxygen atoms on the Pd surface was stronger than the other configurations because the electrons readily migrate from less electronegative atoms to more electronegative atoms, as discussed in previous studies.
(39−41)

An interesting and important finding was that the endothermic reaction for the formation of HCO
3
*
+ H* (the key step that distinguishes HCOO
–
dehydrogenation from HCOOH decomposition on Pd-based catalysts) on the one-sided Pd
12
NC-G system without extra electrons changed into an exothermic reaction on the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G system with extra electrons (reaction step 2 → 3 in
Figure
4
a,b). This finding indicated that the additional electrons could play a significant role in distinguishing between HCOOH decomposition and HCOO
–
dehydrogenation. Although the adsorbed geometry of HCOO
–
was the same as that of HCOO dissociated from HCOOH,
(11,12,42)
the pathways for HCOO
–
and HCOOH dehydrogenation were different. That is, HCOOH generated H
2(g)
by the addition of H (originating from HCOOH dissociation) to CO
2
*
+ H*,
(11,12)
whereas HCOO
–
dehydrogenation followed the reaction pathway in which OH (originating from H
2
O dissociation) was adsorbed on CO
2
*
+ H*, thereby forming HCO
3
*
+ H* (step 2 → 3 in
Figure
4
a). These results validated the use of the developed anion model of HCOO
–
in the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G system; that is, the anion environment was necessary to appropriately describe HCOO
–
dehydrogenation for HCO
3
–
+ H
2(g)
production rather than CO
2(g)
+ H
2(g)
, unlike HCOOH dehydrogenation.

In addition, it was confirmed that HCO
3
–
(g)
production occurred before H
2(g)
production in reaction step 3 → 4 in
Figure
4
a. In the final step (4 → 5), where both products desorbed to form gas-phase products, the highest energy barrier of 1.24 eV and desorption of H from the Pd surface were found to be the reaction potential limiting step in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and the key factor in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation for the production of H
2(g)
, respectively. As observed in previous experimental studies,
(15)
H
2(g)
and HCO
3
–
(g)
were the final products.

div.h3: 3.3. Effect of N-Doping on the Formate Dehydrogenation Pathways
div.div:
To investigate the effect of nitrogen doping on HCOO
–
dehydrogenation, the same dehydrogenation pathways examined in the Pd
12
NC-G system were analyzed with nitrogen-doped models, where the carbon atoms of the two-sided Pd
12
NC-G model with additional electrons were replaced by N dopants. The nitrogen atoms were replaced with the carbon atoms of the graphene adjacent to the Pd
12
NC, and three catalyst models (Pd
12
NC-N
1
G, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G, and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G with 1, 2, and 3 nitrogen atoms, respectively) were designed to examine the effect of the nitrogen-doping ratio on HCOO
–
dehydrogenation. The reaction barriers determined with these models were compared with that of the Pd
12
NC-G system. The sites of nitrogen doped on graphene are shown in
Figure S5
.

As shown in
Figure
5
, the potential limiting step of HCOO
–
dehydrogenation in the Pd
12
NC-N
1
G, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G, and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G models was HCO
3
–
(g)
+ H* → HCO
3
–
(g)
+ H
2(g)
(step 4 → 5), which is similar to the case of the Pd
12
NC-G model. The energy barriers for these models were 1.12, 0.76, and 1.35 eV. The Pd
12
NC-N
1
G and Pd
12
NC-N
2
G models had lower energy barriers than Pd
12
NC-G, in agreement with previous results that nitrogen doping enhances catalytic activity,
(15,20,22,43)
thereby improving the efficiency of HCOO
–
dehydrogenation for H
2(g)
production. In particular, the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G model showed the lowest energy barrier for the potential limiting step (
E
barr
) among the three models because of the relatively weak adsorption of hydrogen (H*). As shown in
Table
1
, the strength of hydrogen adsorption on Pd
12
NC-N
2
G was the weakest, that is the adsorption energy (
E
ads
) was the highest, among those of the three models. This in turn lowered the energy barrier and had a positive effect on H
2(g)
production, which was associated with the electronic and geometrical changes as nitrogen was doped on graphene. Detailed verification of this finding and relevant discussions are included in subsequent sections. Hydrogen adsorption strength may be used as a descriptor (a simple index to estimate the efficiency of reaction on new catalysts) to screen more advanced catalyst materials in future studies on HCOO
–
dehydrogenation.

div.p:
Figure 5. Relative solvation free energy diagram of HCOO
–
dehydrogenation on two-sided Pd
12
NC supported by graphene doped with (a) one nitrogen atom, (b) two nitrogen atoms, and (c) three nitrogen atoms.

div.div: Table 1. Data of Key Factors for the Reversible Formate Dehydrogenation Reactions

div.p:
Adsorption energies of hydrogen per hydrogen atom (
E
ads
_
H
; the lower the value, the stronger is the adsorption).
d-band center values of three clean Pd atoms where H is supposed to be adsorbed.
Sums of spin densities (Σ(spin density)) of the three Pd atom.

Energy barriers of the potential limiting step (
E
barr
) for HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation in the Pd
12
NC-G, Pd
12
NC-N
1
G, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G, and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G systems.

div.div:
The d-band center calculations for the four catalyst systems were performed to verify the effect of nitrogen doping on the energy barrier of the potential limiting step involving hydrogen desorption in the HCOO
–
dehydrogenation pathway. This analysis was confined to the three surface Pd atoms where hydrogen was adsorbed (detailed adsorption sites are shown in
Figure S6
). Among the four catalyst systems, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G showed the smallest d-band center value of −1.391 eV (d-band located farther from the Fermi level) and the lowest adsorption strength (
Table
1
). This agrees well with the results of previous studies in which the d-band center near the Fermi level showed strong adsorption properties.
(44−46)
In addition, the overall trend in the d-band centers and adsorption energies was consistent with that of the energy barrier for HCOO
–
dehydrogenation in each catalyst system. In other words, nitrogen doping induces a positive change in the electronic structure and the appropriate level of doping triggers hydrogen desorption from the Pd surface and promotes HCOO
–
dehydrogenation.

On N doping on graphene, the N 2p orbitals are hybridized with the Pd 4d orbitals, as shown in the projected density of state (PDOS) results in
Figure
6
. The Pd
12
NC-N
2
G system had the smallest band center difference (Δε) between Pd 4d and N 2p (Δε = ε
Pd 4d
– ε
N 2p
= 3.795 eV; corresponding values for the Pd
12
NC-N
1
G and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G systems are 3.988 and 3.839 eV, respectively). Considering that the N 2p band center was farther from the Fermi level than the Pd 4d band center, the smallest Δε demonstrated that the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G system showed the highest degree of hybridization of N 2p and Pd 4d, so that the Pd 4d band center shifted further toward the N 2p band center (away from the Fermi level to a negative value). In other words, the stronger hybridization led the N 2p band to move further toward the Fermi level and the Pd 4d band further away from the Fermi level. Thus, the band center difference (Δε) between N 2p and Pd 4d may be used as another descriptor for screening new advanced materials. The PDOS data for the four surface systems are shown in
Figure S7
.

div.p:
Figure 6. PDOS for clean Pd
12
NC-G and Pd
12
NC-N
2
G. 4d states of three Pd atoms where H is supposed to be adsorbed in (a) Pd
12
NC-G and (b) Pd
12
NC-N
2
G. (c) 2p states of three C atoms where Pd
12
NC is anchored in Pd
12
NC-G. (d) 2p states of one C and two N atoms where Pd
12
NC is anchored in Pd
12
NC-N
2
G. Spin densities of Pd
12
NC in (e) Pd
12
NC-G and (f) Pd
12
NC-N
2
G. Spin-up and spin-down are indicated by positive and negative values, respectively, for convenience.

div.div:
Additionally, the density of states at the Fermi level may contribute to the Pd activity. As the electrons of a transition metal at the Fermi level represent the availability of electrons for bond formation, the greater the number of electrons present at or near the Fermi level, the stronger is the interaction of the transition metal with the adsorbate.
(47,48)
In
Figures
6
a,b and
S7
, which show the PDOS of the Pd 4d states, the Pd electron density of Pd
12
NC-N
2
G at the Fermi level is seen to be the smallest, indicating the weakest interaction between Pd and the key species H, and thus, the lowest energy barrier for the potential limiting step.

Another important factor affecting the H binding strength is the spin density of Pd, that is, the difference between the electron densities of the spin-up and spin-down electrons. Zhang and Xia
(49)
reported that N-doped graphene had asymmetric spin density and hence showed high catalytic activity for the ORR by enhancing the adsorption of ORR intermediates. In the present study, the degree of asymmetric spin density was measured by integrating the area of spin density (Σ(spin density)) as described in
Figure
6
e,f; the larger the Σ(spin density), the higher is the asymmetric spin density. Pd
12
NC-N
2
G showed the smallest Σ(spin density), as listed in
Table
1
, indicating relatively low activity for adsorption. For this reason, the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G system showed lower H adsorption strength, and thus, higher dehydrogenation efficiency than Pd
12
NC-N
3
G, although the d-band centers of both systems were similar. The Σ(spin density) calculation method is described in
Figure S8
.

Electronic analysis was carried out on clean graphene and N-doped graphene to further understand the origin of the smaller Σ(spin density) of the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G system. We confirmed that Σ(spin density) on the clean graphene systems without Pd
12
NC (
Figure
7
a–d) shows a fairly similar trend as that for the three Pd atoms of the four Pd
12
NC in
Table
1
. This result indicated that the smallest Pd Σ(spin density) of Pd
12
NC-N
2
G was due to the fact that the 2N-doped graphene support had the smallest Σ(spin density) among the four graphene supports.

div.p: Figure 7. Top views of (a) monovacancy graphene, (b) 1N-doped graphene, (c) 2N-doped graphene, and (d) 3N-doped graphene. (e) Σ(spin density) of the nine atoms around the vacancy of graphene. Numbers from 1 to 9 represent atoms for which the Σ(spin density) was calculated.

div.div:
The largest Σ(spin density) was observed on the clean graphene without N dopants (
Figure
7
e), which was attributed to dangling bonds formed by the C monovacancy of graphene, as reported previously.
(35,50)
The Σ(spin density) changed depending on the N content (
Figure
7
e), with the smallest value being observed for 2N-doped graphene; this is similar to the so-called “volcano trend”, wherein the best catalytic efficiency can be achieved at the appropriate content of nitrogen or strength of key factors. This result is supported by past studies demonstrating that N dopants beyond a certain concentration improved the magnetic properties of graphene (a higher spin density implies stronger magnetic properties).
(51)
In short, the smallest Σ(spin density) of the 2N-doped graphene causes the Pd Σ(spin density) of the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G system to be the smallest, resulting in weaker hydrogen adsorption and a lower energy barrier for the potential limiting step. This finding was also confirmed by a previous report: the presence of appropriate N dopants on graphene is an important factor in enhancing the ORR efficiency.
(52)
The Σ(spin density) of N-doped graphene can thus be another important key factor that controls formate dehydrogenation on carbon-supported Pd-based catalysts.

To systematically analyze the so-called volcano trend showing the best HCOO
–
dehydrogenation efficiency at the appropriate nitrogen doping, we simplified the Pd catalyst systems by designing Pd
4
NC-G, Pd
4
NC-N
1
G, Pd
4
NC-N
2
G, and Pd
4
NC-N
3
G and compared the Pd d-band centers (
Figure
8
). Although the d-band center values of Pd
4
NC-G (
Figure
8
a) and Pd
4
NC-N
3
G (
Figure
8
d) were the same or similar in each system, Pd
4
NC-N
1
G (
Figure
8
b) and Pd
4
NC-N
2
G (
Figure
8
c) had a wide range of d-band center values because of the presence of nitrogen. Considering the weaker hydrogen adsorption (i.e., smaller d-band center value) and lower energy barrier of the potential limiting step, the Pd
4
NC-N
2
G system would show the optimal balance between the magnitude of reactivity and the number of sites (
Figure
8
f). For example, the lowest d-band center value of −1.48 eV was seen at one site in Pd
4
NC-N
1
G; however, a relatively bigger than −1.48 eV but still sufficiently smaller value of −1.45 eV appeared at two sites in Pd
4
NC-N
2
G. In other words, Pd
4
NC-N
2
G could have a greater number of weak adsorption sites, which was advantageous for hydrogen desorption from the Pd surface than that in the case of Pd
4
NC-N
1
G. This finding indicates that the appropriate level of nitrogen doping on carbon was advantageous for HCOO
–
dehydrogenation as it provided various sites for weak hydrogen atom adsorption on the Pd catalyst.

div.p:
Figure 8. Top views of (a) Pd
4
NC-G, (b) Pd
4
NC-N
1
G, (c) Pd
4
NC-N
2
G, (d) Pd
4
NC-N
3
G with d-band center values, and (e) side views of Pd
4
NC-G. (f) Relative efficiency of Pd
4
NC based on the magnitude of reactivity and the number of sites of d-band centers. Blue, sky blue, pink, and red circles indicate that the closer the color is to blue, the weaker is the H adsorption and that the closer the color is to red, the stronger is the H adsorption.

div.h4: 3.3.4. Geometrical Change of Pd on N Doping
div.div:
An additional interesting point deduced from
Figures
4
and
5
is that the average distance between the six Pd atoms comprising the top layer of Pd
12
NC-N
2
G changed most notably on nitrogen doping. The average distance between the Pd atoms of Pd
12
NC-N
2
G (2.706 Å) was increased by 0.069 Å over that of Pd
12
NC-G (2.637 Å), whereas those of Pd
12
NC-N
1
G and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G slightly reduced by −0.001 and −0.002 Å, respectively, which indicated that the geometry of Pd
12
NC-N
2
G was relatively more strongly reconstructed compared to that of others. In addition, the standard deviation of the average Pd distance in Pd
12
NC-N
2
G (0.284 Å) was significantly greater than those in Pd
12
NC-N
1
G and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G (0.088 and 0.061 Å, respectively), demonstrating that the catalytic surface of Pd
12
NC-N
1
G had the largest range of interatomic Pd distances among the four catalyst systems. This phenomenon could be attributed to the strain effect by nitrogen doping as reported previously (dopants can exert tensile and/or compressive strain on the surface system).
(53,54)
In the current study, the aforesaid strain effect was also reflected in the distance between the bottom of graphene and the interface where Pd
12
NC was anchored on graphene (
Figure S9
). As compressive strain may decrease the adsorption strength of the adsorbate on transition metals [e.g., O on Pt(111),
(47)
CO on Ru(0001),
(44)
CO and CHO on Cu(111),
(55)
the significantly decreased Pd atom distance in Pd
12
NC-N
2
G could help lower the energy barrier of the potential limiting step in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation by weakening hydrogen adsorption. In addition, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G had the most number of sites affected by the compressive strain (
Table S18
). Therefore, the appropriate level of nitrogen doping could be beneficial for the electronic structure and the surface geometry, which influences the formation of various adsorption sites for improved HCOO
–
dehydrogenation. Detailed data on the interatomic distances are shown in Section S8 in
Supporting Information
.

In summary, changes in the electronic and geometrical properties because of N doping influence the adsorption strength of hydrogen, which is the key factor in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation. The hydrogen adsorption strength on Pd
12
NC-N
2
G, which is most notably affected by the N dopant among the four catalyst systems, is approximately 0.33 eV lower than that for Pd
12
NC-G. An important finding deduced from this result is that new Pd-based catalysts with moderately weaker hydrogen adsorption than Pd nanoparticles enhance the HCOO
–
dehydrogenation efficiency. This hypothesis is supported by previously known facts in the ORR
(56,57)
and hydrogen evolution reaction
(58,59)
that the appropriate adsorption strength of a key species plays an important role in enhancing the reaction efficiency. For example, catalysts with higher ORR efficiency than Pt catalysts require an oxygen adsorption strength 0.2–0.4 eV lower than that of Pt catalyst for efficient conversion of the reaction intermediates.
(56,57)

Nitrogen doping was confirmed to enhance the efficiency of HCOO
–
dehydrogenation, but a negative effect was also observed. The Pd
12
NC-N
3
G model with the highest N dopant level showed a higher energy barrier than did the Pd
12
NC-G model (without the dopant), and consequently, had the highest energy barrier. This implies that excessive nitrogen doping might adversely affect HCOO
–
dehydrogenation. Thus, appropriate nitrogen doping can be a key factor in optimizing the efficiency of HCOO
–
dehydrogenation for the production of H
2(g)
.

Hydrogenation of HCO
3
–
, the reverse reaction of HCOO
–
dehydrogenation, was analyzed on the four catalyst systems. As shown in
Figure
3
b, the most stable pathway for the hydrogenation of HCO
3
–
was as follows: HCO
3
*
→ HCO
3
*
+ H* → CO
2
*
+ H
2
O
(g)
→ HCOO* + H
2
O
(g)
→ HCOO
–
(g)
+ H
2
O
(g)
. HCO
3
–
hydrogenation was initiated by the formation of HCO
3
*
+ H* via the adsorption of H on the Pd surface (reaction step 1 → 2 in
Figure
9
), which was energetically more stable than H
2
CO
3
*
formation (by the adsorption H on HCO
3
*
or formation of CO
2
*
+ OH* by the desorption of OH from HCO
3
*
) in all four models. Note that the adsorbed H* source for the formation of HCO
3
*
+ H* originated from the dissociation of H
2(g)
on the Pd surface. This indicated that H
2(g)
essentially dissociated first to induce the hydrogenation of HCO
3
–
, which agrees well with the result of experimental studies.
(15,60)
A notable feature here is that the reaction from step 1 to step 2 (HCO
3
*
→ HCO
3
*
+ H*) in the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G system is exothermic, whereas the other steps are endothermic (
Figure
9
c); this is because the adsorption of HCO
3
*
on Pd
12
NC-N
2
G in step 1 is energetically less stable than that in the other models. As discussed above in the HCOO
–
dehydrogenation pathways, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G is electronically and geometrically the most affected by N doping, providing weaker adsorption sites on the Pd catalyst surface as compared to those on the other catalysts.

div.p:
Figure 9. Relative solvation free energy diagrams of HCO
3
–
hydrogenation on the two-sided Pd
12
NC systems: (a) graphene-, (b) 1N-doped graphene-, (c) 2N-doped graphene-, and (d) 3N-doped graphene-supported Pd
12
NC. Black solid line with filled rectangles represents the most stable reaction pathway for HCO
3
–
hydrogenation.

div.div:
In the next step (2 → 3), where H
2
O
(g)
was produced by the combination of H dissociated from H
2(g)
and OH desorbed from HCO
3
*
, the potential limiting step was observed, and similar results were seen for all four catalyst models (
Figure
9
). The energy barriers for the potential limiting steps in the Pd
12
NC-G, N
1
G, N
2
G, and N
3
G systems were 1.49, 1.27, 0.96, and 1.90 eV, respectively. Similar to HCOO
–
dehydrogenation, the lowest energy barrier was observed in the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G model. Additionally, in the potential limiting step, desorption of H from the Pd surface was the key factor for HCO
3
–
hydrogenation, as in the case of HCOO
–
dehydrogenation. This could be explained by the weaker binding strength between the CO
2
and OH constituents in the HCO
3
*
molecule than in the adsorbed H* on the Pd surface. In the case of Pd
12
NC-G, Pd
12
NC-N
1
G, Pd
12
NC-N
2
G, and Pd
12
NC-N
3
G, the binding energies (energy required to break a bond) of the OH constituent in the HCO
3
*
molecule were −0.10, −0.22, −0.71, and 0.19 eV, respectively, which were smaller than the adsorption strength of H on the Pd surface (
Table
1
). In other words, the energy barrier of the potential limiting step was mainly due to the detachment of H from the Pd surface rather than the dissociation of the OH constituent in the HCO
3
*
molecule. Thus, as with the HCOO
–
dehydrogenation, the weaker adsorption of H on the Pd surface not only improved the efficiency of HCO
3
–
hydrogenation by lowering the energy barrier of the potential limiting step but also acted as a descriptor for HCO
3
–
hydrogenation.

In the following step (3 → 4), HCOO* + H
2
O
(g)
were formed through the adsorption of H on CO
2
*
. This step demonstrated that the H atoms for the formation of H
2
O and HCOO
–
originated from the dissociation of H
2(g)
, indicating that HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation were reversible. In the final step (4 → 5), the reaction was terminated by the desorption of HCOO
–
(g)
and H
2
O
(g)
from the Pd surface.

div.h3: 3.5. Uncertainty Analysis of the Energy Barrier on N Locations
div.div:
To assure best efficiency of the Pd
12
NC-N
2
G system for the HCOO
–
and HCO
3
–
reversible reactions, as demonstrated in
Figures
4
,
5
, and
9
, the energy barriers for the potential limiting steps in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation were recalculated depending on the different locations of the N dopants in graphene. Although the energy barrier values were different from those listed in
Table
1
, the conditions for the N doping to be the most effective were similar in both cases, demonstrating that the appropriate number of nitrogen atoms (2N-doped model) has a greater effect on the HCOO
–
and HCO
3
–
reversible reactions. Details of the data are shown in
Supporting Information
Section S9.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We analyzed the fundamental mechanisms underlying reversible HCOO
–
dehydrogenation and HCO
3
–
hydrogenation for H
2
production, which have not yet been experimentally clarified. The graphene-supported two-sided Pd
12
NC models with extra electrons proposed in this study adequately simulated the anion environment by maximizing the localization of electrons near the catalyst surface where the reversible reactions occurred. Using the developed supercell models, we found that the HCOO
–
was dehydrogenated via the sequence HCOO* → CO
2
*
+ H* → HCO
3
*
+ H* → HCO
3
–
(g)
+ H* → HCO
3
–
(g)
+ H
2(g)
and that HCO
3
–
was hydrogenated via the reverse reaction. The H atom of HCOO
–
and H
2
O acted as the source for H
2(g)
in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation; in HCO
3
–
hydrogenation, H
2(g)
was dissociated and distributed between HCOO
–
and H
2
O. Thus, despite having the same molecular structure as formic acid, formate undergoes decomposition via a completely different pathway.

The potential limiting step in HCOO
–
dehydrogenation was the final step of H
2(g)
desorption, and the energy barriers were 1.24, 1.12, 0.76, and 1.35 eV on Pd
12
NC-G, Pd
12
NC-G-N
1
G, Pd
12
NC-G-N
2
G, and Pd
12
NC-G-N
3
G, respectively. On the other hand, the limiting step in HCO
3
–
hydrogenation corresponded to HCO
3
*
+ H* → CO
2
*
+ H
2
O
(g)
, and the corresponding energy barriers were 1.49, 1.27, 0.96, and 1.90 eV in the four models. Notably, despite the different potential limiting steps in the reversible reaction, desorption of hydrogen from the Pd catalyst was the key factor that determines the limiting steps for the HCOO
–
and HCO
3
–
reversible reactions. In other words, relatively weaker adsorption of atomic hydrogen on a Pd NC (approximately 0.33 eV lower energy than that on Pd) will result in more efficient dehydrogenation and hydrogenation.

The efficiency of the Pd catalyst for the HCOO
–
and HCO
3
–
reversible reactions was determined by (1) shift of the Pd d-band center to a more negative value by hybridization with the more negative N 2p orbital of the N-doped graphene; and (2) the low spin density of the graphene support, which affects the low spin density of the Pd catalyst. Although the Pd d-band center can be sufficiently shifted to a more negative value at a certain level of N doping, excessive doping would increase the spin density of graphene. This in turn increases the spin density of Pd, resulting in stronger H adsorption, and eventually, a decrease in the H
2(g)
generation efficiency. Additionally, the lower electron density of Pd at the Fermi level may contribute to weakening the H adsorption, thus lowering the energy barrier for the potential limiting step.

Obviously, the 2N-doped Pd
12
NC, with the adequate level of N doping, exhibits the best dehydrogenation and hydrogenation efficiency, demonstrating that a proper amount of nitrogen dopant on a carbon support would have the most positive effect on the electronic and geometrical properties of the Pd surface, thereby playing an important role in enhancing the efficiency of the reversible reactions. However, excessive nitrogen doping may deteriorate the conversion efficiency. Therefore, determining the optimal N doping ratio is the most important factor in improving the conversion efficiency of HCOO
–
and HCO
3
–
reversible reactions.

A review. This article deals with hydrogen energy as a clean energy carrier, discusses the key role of hydrogen energy technologies and systems, and compares hydrogen with other energy forms. Energy strategies that incorporate hydrogen are considered, and the importance of hydrogen energy in achieving a sustainable energy system is discussed. Exergetic, environmental, sustainability and other perspectives are considered.

A review. Hydrogen is a promising energy carrier in future energy systems. However, storage of hydrogen is a substantial challenge, esp. for applications in vehicles with fuel cells that use proton exchange membranes. Different methods for hydrogen storage are discussed, including high-pressure and cryogenic-liq. storage, adsorptive storage on high-surface-area adsorbents, chem. storage in metal hydrides and complex hydrides, and storage in boranes. For the latter chem. solns., reversible options and hydrolytic release of hydrogen with off-board regeneration are both possible. Reforming of liq. hydrogen-contg. compds. is also a possible means of hydrogen generation. The advantages and disadvantages of the different systems are compared.

The authors report a novel catalyst that uses CO2 and H2 to store energy in formic acid. Using a homogeneous Ir catalyst with a proton-responsive ligand, they show the first reversible and recyclable hydrogen storage system that operates under mild conditions using CO2, formate and formic acid. This system is energy-efficient and green because it operates near ambient conditions, uses water as a solvent, produces high-pressure CO-free H2, and uses pH to control hydrogen prodn. or consumption. The extraordinary and switchable catalytic activity is attributed to the multifunctional ligand, which acts as a proton-relay and strong π-donor, and is rationalized by theor. and exptl. studies.

A review. Formic acid has recently been suggested as a promising hydrogen storage material. The basic concept is briefly discussed and the recent advances in the development of formic acid dehydrogenation catalysts are shown. Both the state of research for heterogeneous and for homogeneous catalyst systems are reviewed in detail and an outlook on necessary development steps is presented. Formic acid is considered as one of the most promising materials for hydrogen storage today. There are a no. of highly active and robust homogeneous catalysts that selectively decomp. formic acid to H2 and CO2 near to room temp. Although the activity and selectivity of heterogeneous catalysts have not yet reached the level of homogeneous systems, this gap is closing.

Periodic d. functional theory calcns. are employed to det. the reaction energetics of formic acid decompn. on Ag, Cu, Pd, Pt, and Rh surfaces. The authors also extend the study to other transition-metal surfaces by scaling the adsorption energies of the reaction species with 2 independent descriptors: CO and OH adsorption energies. A microkinetic model is then developed to derive the kinetics of formic acid decompn. from the energy parameters. By incorporating the scaling relations in the microkinetic model, the turnover frequencies for formic acid decompn. over the transition-metal surfaces are described as functions of the 2 descriptors. The variations in catalytic activity and selectivity from one metal surface to another, which are obtained from the 1st principles anal., are in qual. agreement with those obtained exptl. The interpolation concept of adsorption energy is finally used to conveniently identify potentially interesting alloy catalysts for formic acid decompn.

The authors present a 1st-principles, self-consistent periodic d. functional theory (PW91-GGA) study of formic acid (HCOOH) decompn. on model (111) and (100) facets of eight fcc. metals (Au, Ag, Cu, Pt, Pd, Ni, Ir, and Rh) and (0001) facets of four hcp. (Co, Os, Ru, and Re) metals. The calcd. binding energies of key formic acid decompn. intermediates including formate (HCOO), carboxyl (COOH), CO, H2O (H2O), CO2 (CO2), hydroxyl (OH), C, O (O), and H (H; H2) are presented. Using these energetics, the authors develop thermochem. potential energy diagrams for both the carboxyl-mediated and the formate-mediated dehydrogenation mechanisms on each surface. The authors evaluate the relative stability of COOH, HCOO, and other isomeric intermediates (i.e., CO + OH, CO2 + H, CO + O + H) on these surfaces. These results provide insights into formic acid decompn. selectivity (dehydrogenation vs. dehydration), and in conjunction with calcd. vibrational frequency modes, the results can assist with the exptl. search for the elusive carboxyl (COOH) surface intermediate. Results are compared against exptl. reports in the literature.

Vapor phase decompn. of formic acid has been studied systematically over a range of catalysts: 1.0 and 10 wt. % Pd/C, 0.8 wt. % Au/C and 1.0 wt.% Au/TiO2. The mean metal particle size of these materials was estd. by HRTEM and turnover frequencies were calcd. using these data. The Au/C catalyst was the least active and the Pd/C catalysts were the most active for the formic acid decompn. reaction. At about 400 K, these Pd catalysts gave up to 0.04 mol of H2 per min per g of Pd, with a selectivity of 95-99%. The H2 selectivity for these catalysts was found to be only weakly dependent on the reaction temp. and the formic acid conversion. The Au/TiO2 catalyst showed only a moderate selectivity to H2 formation (<70%). The selectivity of this catalyst was improved considerably by the introduction of water vapor. This improvement derived from the high activity of the catalyst for the water-gas shift reaction.

The reversible reactions involving formate and bicarbonate can be used to store and release hydrogen (H2), allowing H2 to serve as an effective energy carrier in energy systems such as fuel cells. However, to feasibly utilize these reactions for renewable energy applications, efficient catalysts that can reversibly promote both reactions are required. Herein we report the synthesis of novel polyaniline (PANI)-derived mesoporous carbon-supported Pd nanoparticles, or materials that can efficiently catalyze these reversible reactions. The synthesis involves pyrolysis of PANI/colloidal silica composite materials at temps. above 500 °C, followed by removal of the colloidal silica from the carbonized products with an alk. soln. and finally deposition of Pd nanoparticles within the mesoporous carbon products. The resulting nanomaterials efficiently catalyze the reversible reactions, i.e., the dehydrogenation of formate (HCO2- + H2O → H2 + HCO3-) and the hydrogenation of bicarbonate (H2 + HCO3- → H2O + HCO2-). The porosity and the catalytic property of the materials can be tailored, or improved, by changing the synthetic conditions (in particular, the pyrolysis temp. and the amt. of colloidal silica used for making the materials). The study further reveals that having an optimum d. of N dopant species in the catalysts makes Pd to exhibit high catalytic activity toward both reactions. Among the different materials studied here, the one synthesized at 800 °C with relatively high amt. of colloidal silica template gives the best catalytic activity, with a turnover frequency (TOF) of 2,562 h-1 for the dehydrogenation reaction and a turnover no. (TON) of 1,625 for the hydrogenation reaction.

The vapor-phase decompn. of formic acid was studied over Pt metals supported on inert C Norit with the aim of producing CO-free H2. FTIR spectroscopy revealed that formic acid dissocd. on Pt metals at 220-240 K, but the formate species formed was stable only <300-350 K. Decompn. of formic acid started at and >350 K on all catalysts and was complete at 473-523 K. Kinetic studies on Pt/Norit demonstrated that the decompn. was a zero-order process with an activation energy of 70.7 kJ/mol. Although dehydrogenation was the predominant process at lower temps., CO-free H2 was not produced on any catalyst. The highest selectivity of 98.3-99% for H2 formation was attained on Ir/Norit. For all catalysts, the selectivity was improved considerably by the addn. of H2O to formic acid. The prodn. of CO-free H2 was achieved only on supported Ir at 383-473 K. Similarly, as regards the H2 yield the outstanding catalyst was Ir/Norit, followed by Pt/Norit.

Formic acid has great potential as an in situ source of hydrogen for fuel cells, because it offers high energy d., is nontoxic and can be safely handled in aq. soln. So far, there has been a lack of solid catalysts that are sufficiently active and/or selective for hydrogen prodn. from formic acid at room temp. Here, we report that Ag nanoparticles coated with a thin layer of Pd atoms can significantly enhance the prodn. of H2 from formic acid at ambient temp. Atom probe tomog. confirmed that the nanoparticles have a core-shell configuration, with the shell contg. between 1 and 10 layers of Pd atoms. The Pd shell contains terrace sites and is electronically promoted by the Ag core, leading to significantly enhanced catalytic properties. Our nanocatalysts could be used in the development of micro polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells for portable devices and could also be applied in the promotion of other catalytic reactions under mild conditions.

Reversible, carbon dioxide mediated chem. hydrogen storage was first demonstrated using a heterogeneous Pd catalyst supported on mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (Pd/mpg-C3N4). The Pd nanoparticles were found to be uniformly dispersed onto mpg-C3N4 with an av. size of 1.7 nm without any agglomeration and further exhibit superior activity for the dehydrogenation of formic acid with a turnover frequency of 144 h-1 even in the absence of external bases at room temp. Initial DFT studies suggest that basic sites located at the mpg-C3N4 support play synergetic roles in stabilizing reduced Pd nanoparticles without any surfactant as well as in initiating H2-release by deprotonation of formic acid, and these potential interactions were further confirmed by X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES). Along with dehydrogenation, Pd/mpg-C3N4 also proves to catalyze the regeneration of formic acid via CO2 hydrogenation. The governing factors of CO2 hydrogenation are further elucidated to increase the quantity of the desired formic acid with high selectivity.

In this study, we explore the effect of light nonmetal dopants (e.g., boron, carbon, and nitrogen) on the catalytic properties of transition-metal surfaces using the recently discovered boron-doped palladium catalyst for formic acid decompn. as an example. We use periodic d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. to derive an understanding of how subsurface boron modifies the palladium catalyst to be more active, and we find that the effect of the boron modification of palladium is different depending on the class of an adsorbate. Our DFT calcn. results are also coupled to the microkinetic model of formic acid decompn. published previously to show that the catalytic properties of boron-doped palladium can be analyzed within the same conceptual framework used for understanding the catalytic trends of (undoped) transition-metal and alloy catalysts.

The success of the so-called "hydrogen economy" for large-scale applications will ultimately depend on efficient and sustainable prodn., storage and distribution of hydrogen. Owing to its low toxicity, high volumetric H2 storage capacity and availability both from renewable resources (e.g., biomass) and non-renewable resources (e.g., fossil fuel feedstocks), formic acid is one of the most favorable chem. hydrogen storage media for large-scale energy storage applications. However, for formic acid to become a viable hydrogen storage medium, efficient catalysts that enable it to release H2 at low cost are necessary. Herein we report a facile synthetic route to amine-functionalized nanoporous silica-supported ultrasmall Pd nanoparticles (SBA-15-Amine/Pd) that are highly active catalysts for formic acid dehydrogenation, producing hydrogen at ambient temp. with a high turn-over-frequency (TOF) of 293 h-1, which is among the highest TOFs ever reported for the reaction by a heterogeneous catalyst. We also show that the material is easily recyclable multiple times, without losing its catalytic activity. So, the catalyst we developed can be expected to be part of the solns. of our sustainability challenges.

The formate-based rechargeable hydrogen battery (RHB) promises high reversible capacity to meet the need for safe, reliable, and sustainable H2 storage used in fuel cell applications. Described herein is an additive-free RHB which is based on repetitive cycles operated between aq. formate dehydrogenation (discharging) and bicarbonate hydrogenation (charging). Key to this truly efficient and durable H2 handling system is the use of highly strained Pd nanoparticles anchored on graphite oxide nanosheets as a robust and efficient solid catalyst, which can facilitate both the discharging and charging processes in a reversible and highly facile manner. Up to six repeated discharging/charging cycles can be performed without noticeable degrdn. in the storage capacity.

The authors present an efficient scheme for calcg. the Kohn-Sham ground state of metallic systems using pseudopotentials and a plane-wave basis set. In the first part the application of Pulay's DIIS method (direct inversion in the iterative subspace) to the iterative diagonalization of large matrixes will be discussed. This approach is stable, reliable, and minimizes the no. of order Natoms3 operations. In the second part, we will discuss an efficient mixing scheme also based on Pulay's scheme. A special "metric" and a special "preconditioning" optimized for a plane-wave basis set will be introduced. Scaling of the method will be discussed in detail for non-self-consistent and self-consistent calcns. It will be shown that the no. of iterations required to obtain a specific precision is almost independent of the system size. Altogether an order Natoms2 scaling is found for systems contg. up to 1000 electrons. If we take into account that the no. of k points can be decreased linearly with the system size, the overall scaling can approach Natoms. They have implemented these algorithms within a powerful package called VASP (Vienna ab initio simulation package). The program and the techniques have been used successfully for a large no. of different systems (liq. and amorphous semiconductors, liq. simple and transition metals, metallic and semiconducting surfaces, phonons in simple metals, transition metals, and semiconductors) and turned out to be very reliable.

The formal relationship between ultrasoft (US) Vanderbilt-type pseudopotentials and Blochl's projector augmented wave (PAW) method is derived. The total energy functional for US pseudopotentials can be obtained by linearization of two terms in a slightly modified PAW total energy functional. The Hamilton operator, the forces, and the stress tensor are derived for this modified PAW functional. A simple way to implement the PAW method in existing plane-wave codes supporting US pseudopotentials is pointed out. In addn., crit. tests are presented to compare the accuracy and efficiency of the PAW and the US pseudopotential method with relaxed-core all-electron methods. These tests include small mols. (H2, H2O, Li2, N2, F2, BF3, SiF4) and several bulk systems (diamond, Si, V, Li, Ca, CaF2, Fe, Co, Ni). Particular attention is paid to the bulk properties and magnetic energies of Fe, Co, and Ni.

A sampling method is given for Brillouin-zone integration in metals which converges exponentially with the no. of sampling points, without the loss of precision of normal broadening techniques. The scheme is based on smooth approximants to the δ and step functions which are constructed to give the exact result when integrating polynomials of a prescribed degree. In applications to the simple-cubic tight-binding band as well as to band structures of simple and transition metals, significant improvement over existing methods was shown. The method promises general applicability in the fields of total-energy calcns. and many-body physics.

This work established linear scaling relations for the dissociative reaction intermediates NH, NH2, and NH3. Linear scaling relations for the associative reaction intermediates N2H, N2H2, and N2H3 were detd. Also, correlations between the adsorption energies of N, N2, and H were established. NH3 prodn. and hence describe the potential detg. steps for the electrochem. NH3 prodn. The competing H evolution reaction also was analyzed for comparison.

The structural and electronic properties of Pt13 nanoparticles adsorbed on monovacancy defective graphene have been detd. to understand oxygen adsorption on Pt nanoparticles based upon d. functional theory predictions using the generalized gradient approxn. We demonstrate that a monovacancy site of graphene serves a key role as an anchoring point for Pt13 nanoparticles, ensuring their stability on defective graphene surfaces and suggesting their enhanced catalytic activity toward the interaction with O2. Strong hybridization of the Pt13 nanoparticle with the sp2 dangling bonds of neighboring carbon atoms near the monovacancy site leads to the strong binding of the Pt13 nanoparticle on defective graphene (-7.45 eV in adsorption energy). Upon both adsorption of the Pt13 nanoparticle on defective graphene and O2 on Pt13-defective graphene, strong charge depletion of the Pt atom at the interfaces of Pt-C and Pt-O2 is obsd. Pt13 nanoparticles are able to donate charge to both defective graphene and O2. The Pt13-defective graphene complex shows an O2 adsorption energy of -2.30 eV, which is weaker than the O2 adsorption energy of -3.92 eV on a free Pt13 nanoparticle. Considering the strong stability of the Pt nanoparticles and relatively weaker O2 adsorption energy due to the defective graphene support, we expect that the defective graphene support may increase the catalytic activity of Pt nanoparticles compared to flat Pt metal surfaces, not only by preventing sintering of Pt nanoparticles due to the strong anchoring nature of the graphene defect sites but also by providing a balance in the O2 binding strength that may allow for enhanced catalyst turnover.

The mechanisms of the O redn. reaction (ORR) on defective graphene-supported Pt13 nanoparticles were studied to understand the effect of defective graphene support on the ORR and predict details of ORR pathways. The authors employed d. functional theory (DFT) predictions using the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method within the generalized gradient approxn. (GGA). Free energy diagrams for the ORR over supported and unsupported Pt13 nanoparticles were constructed to provide the stability of possible intermediates in the electrochem. reaction pathways. The defective graphene support may provide a balance in the binding of ORR intermediates on Pt13 nanoparticles by tuning the relatively high reactivity of free Pt13 nanoparticles that bind the ORR intermediates too strongly subsequently leading to slow kinetics. The defective graphene support lowers not only the activation energy for O2 dissocn. from 0.37 to 0.16 eV, but also the energy barrier of the rate-limiting step by reducing the stability of HO* species. The authors predict the ORR mechanisms via direct four-electron and series two-electron pathways. An activation free energy (0.16 eV) for O2 dissocn. from adsorbed O2* at a bridge site on the supported Pt13 nanoparticle into O* + O* species (i.e., the direct pathway) is lower than the free energy barrier (0.29 eV) for the formation of HOO* species from adsorbed O2* at the corresponding atop site, indicating that the direct pathway may be preferred as the initial step of the ORR mechanism. Also, charge is transferred from the Pt13 nanoparticle to both defective graphene and the ORR intermediate species.

The structural, electronic, and magnetic properties of Fe13 and Al13 nanoparticles adsorbed on monovacancy defective graphene have been detd. using d. functional theory with the generalized gradient approxn. (GGA). Graphene vacancies are used as anchoring points for these pure metal nanoparticles, ensuring their isolated stability on the surface, thereby maximizing their catalytic reactivity through the availability of undercoordinated surface sites along with a high surface area. The results of this work indicate that the strong binding of Fe13 and Al13 nanoparticles on defective graphene (-6.98 and -3.84 eV in adsorption energy, resp.) is due to strong hybridization of the nanoparticles with the sp2 dangling bonds of neighboring carbons near the vacancy. Charge difference and Bader charge analyses of the Fe13 and Al13 adsorbed systems suggest that charge redistribution of defective graphene occurs to a greater extent in the Fe13 system than in the Al13 system due to the strongly hybridized Fe13 d-states with the monovacancy defective site of graphene. For the Fe13 nanoparticle, upon adsorption its d-band center shifts closer to the Fermi level from -1.28 to -1.13 eV, indicating a potential increase in the catalytic reactivity assocd. with the graphene surface.

A review. Electrochem. capacitors, also called supercapacitors, store energy using either ion adsorption (electrochem. double layer capacitors) or fast surface redox reactions (pseudo-capacitors). A notable improvement in performance has been achieved through recent advances in understanding charge storage mechanisms and the development of advanced nanostructured materials. The discovery that ion desolvation occurs in pores smaller than the solvated ions has led to higher capacitance for electrochem. double layer capacitors using carbon electrodes with sub-nanometer pores, and opened the door to designing high-energy d. devices using a variety of electrolytes. Combination of pseudo-capacitive nanomaterials, including oxides, nitrides and polymers, with the latest generation of nanostructured lithium electrodes has brought the energy d. of electrochem. capacitors closer to that of batteries. The use of carbon nanotubes has further advanced micro-electrochem. capacitors, enabling flexible and adaptable devices to be made. Math. modeling and simulation will be the key to success in designing tomorrow's high-energy and high-power devices.

The N-doped graphene (NG) with dominance of the pyridinic-N configuration is synthesized via a straightforward process including CVD growth of graphene and postdoping with a solid N precursor of graphitic C3N4 at elevated temp. The NG fabricated from CVD-grown graphene contains a high N content up to 6.5 at.% when postdoped at 800° but maintains high cryst. quality of graphene. The obtained NG exhibits high activity, long-standing stability, and outstanding crossover resistance for electrocatalysis of O redn. reaction (ORR) in alk. medium. The NG treated at 800° shows the best ORR performance. Further study of the dependence of ORR activity on different N functional groups in these metal-free NG electrodes provides deeper insights into the origin of ORR activity. The pyridinic-N tends to be the most active N functional group to facilitate ORR at low overpotential via a 4-electron pathway.

Precision is given to the concept of electronegativity. It is the neg. of the chem. potential (the Lagrange multiplier for the normalization constraint) in the Hohenberg-Kohn d. functional theory. Electronegativity is const. throughout an atom or mol., and const. from orbital to orbital within an atom or mol. Definitions are given of the concepts of an atom in a mol. and of a valence state of an atom in a mol., and it shown how valence-state electronegativity differences drive charge transfer on mol. formation. An equation of Gibbs-Duhem type is given for the change of electronegativity from one situation to another, and some discussion is given of certain relations among energy components discovered by Fraga.

The crit. role of the Ag-Pd ligand effect (which is tuned by changing the no. of Pd at. layers) in detg. the dehydrogenation and dehydration of HCOOH on the bimetallic Pd/Ag catalysts was elucidated by using the spin-polarized d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. Our calcns. suggest that the selectivity to H2 prodn. from HCOOH on the bimetallic Pd/Ag catalysts strongly depends on the Pd at. layer thickness at near surface. In particular, the thinnest Pd monolayer in the Pd/Ag system is responsible for enhancing the selectivity of HCOOH decompn. toward H2 prodn. by reducing the surface binding strength of specific intermediates such as HCOO and HCO. The dominant Ag-Pd ligand effect by the substantial charge donation to the Pd surface from the subsurface Ag [which significantly reduce the d. of state (particularly, dz2-r2 orbital) near the Fermi level] proves to be a key factor for the selective hydrogen prodn. from HCOOH decompn., whereas the expansive (tensile) strain imposed by the underlying Ag substrate plays a minor role. This work hints on the importance of properly engineering the surface activity of the Ag-Pd core-shell catalysts by the interplay between ligand and strain effects.

Nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbons (NMCs) with controllable nitrogen doping and similar mesoporous structures are prepd. by a facile colloidal silica nanocasting method using melamine, phenol, and formaldehyde as precursors. Various physicochem. properties, such as the oxidn. stability, the cond. and the electrochem. capacitive performance, the CO2 adsorption, the basicity, and the metal-free catalytic activity of the NMCs, are studied extensively in relation to the incorporation amt. of nitrogen in the carbon backbone. The dependence of the oxidn. stability and the cond. of the NMCs on the nitrogen content are similar; both of the biggest improvements are achieved at a low nitrogen content of ca. 4.2 wt. %. While used as the supercapacitor electrodes, the NMCs with a mediate nitrogen content of ca. 8 wt. % can take full advantage of the nitrogen-induced pseudocapacitance and the nitrogen-enhanced cond., delivering an excellent high-rate capacitive performance. The nitrogen content does not play an important role in the CO2 phys. adsorption, where the effect of microporosity prevails over the nitrogen-doped carbon surface. However, the nitrogen content dets. the basicity of the NMCs, which governs their CO2 chem. adsorption ability and the metal-free catalytic activity for direct oxidn. of H2S. The higher the nitrogen content, the higher the basicity and the catalytic activity. Our studies give a reliable relationship between nitrogen doping and the physicochem. properties of mesoporous carbons, which should provide a useful guide to their practical applications.

The conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) into usable hydrocarbon fuels is important for recycling carbon resources and mitigating environmental problems. However, converting CO2, which is a stable compd., requires a high addnl. energy. Therefore, it is essential to understand the electrochem. redn. mechanisms of CO2 and develop more efficient catalysts. In this study, d. functional theory calcns. were performed to examine electrochem. CO2 redn. on copper nanoclusters (NCs) (Cu13 NCs and Cu55 NCs) and the Cu(1 1 1) surface to verify the effect of the surface geometry and size of the NCs on the conversion of CO2 into CH4. The highest energy barriers to CO2 redn. (i.e., the potential-limiting step) on the Cu13 NCs (0.64 eV), Cu55 NCs (0.83 eV), and Cu(1 1 1) surface (0.86 eV) lie in the CO* → CHO* step. The formation of an adsorbed CHO intermediate depending on the catalyst surface geometry may significantly influence the energy barrier, as demonstrated by analyses of the electronic properties, such as the d. of states, charge d. difference, and HOMO and LUMO band gap.

The effect of alloying with transition metals (Ni, Co, Fe) on the adsorption strength of phosphoric acid on Pt alloy surfaces was investigated using electrochemical analysis and first-principles calculations. Cyclic voltammograms of carbon-supported Pt3M/C (M = Ni, Co, and Fe) electrocatalysts in 0.1 M HClO4 with and without 0.01 M H3PO4 revealed that the phosphoric acid adsorption charge density near the onset potential on the nanoparticle surfaces was decreased by alloying with transition metals in the order Co, Fe, Ni. Blonski, Piotr; Tucek, Jiri; Sofer, Zdenek; Mazanek, Vlastimil; Petr, Martin; Pumera, Martin; Otyepka, Michal; Zboril, Radek
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2017
),
139
(
8
),
3171-3180
CODEN:
JACSAT
; ISSN:
0002-7863
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Nitrogen doping opens possibilities for tailoring the electronic properties and band gap of graphene towards its applications, e.g., in spintronics and optoelectronics. One major obstacle is development of magnetically active N-doped graphene with spin-polarized conductive behavior. However, the effect of nitrogen on the magnetic properties of graphene has so far only been addressed theor. and triggering of magnetism through N-doping has not yet been proved exptl., except for systems contg. a high amt. of oxygen and thus decreased cond. Here, we report the first example of ferromagnetic graphene achieved by controlled doping with graphitic, pyridinic, and chemisorbed nitrogen. The magnetic properties were found to depend strongly on both the nitrogen concn. and type of structural N-motifs generated in the host lattice. Graphenes doped below 5 at.% of nitrogen were nonmagnetic; however, once doped at 5.1 at.% of nitrogen, N-doped graphene exhibited transition to a ferromagnetic state at ∼69 K and displayed a satn. magnetization reaching 1.09 emu/g. Theor. calcns. were used to elucidate the effects of individual chem. forms of nitrogen on magnetic properties. Results showed that magnetic effects were triggered by graphitic nitrogen, whereas pyridinic and chemisorbed nitrogen contributed much less to the overall ferromagnetic ground state. Calcns. further proved the existence of exchange coupling among the paramagnetic centers mediated by the conduction electrons.

52
Manageable N-doped graphene for high performance oxygen reduction reaction
Zhang Yuewei; Ge Jun; Wang Lu; Wang Donghong; Ding Feng; Tao Xiaoming; Chen Wei
Scientific reports
(
2013
),
3
(
),
2771
ISSN:
.
Catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) are at the heart of key green-energy fuel cell technology. N-doped graphene is a potential metal-free electrode with much better electrocatalytic activity, long-term stability, and tolerance to crossover effect than expensive platinum-based electrocatalysts. Here, we report a feasible direct-synthesis method in preparing N-graphene with manageable N contents in a large scale. The resultant N-graphene used as electrocatalysts exhibits similar catalytic activity but superior stability compared to commercial Pt/C for ORR in an alkaline solution. It was found that their electrocatalytic activities were demonstrated to depend largely on N-doping content. When nitrogen content reaches a high value at about 24-25%, ORR reaction exhibits a favorable formation of water via a four-electron pathway. Furthermore, the effect of pyrolysis temperature and precursor on the activity of N-graphene is systematically analyzed, and may shed some light on the principle of choosing appropriate way for preparing N-graphene.

Covalent Nitrogen Doping and Compressive Strain in MoS2 by Remote N2 Plasma Exposure
Azcatl, Angelica; Qin, Xiaoye; Prakash, Abhijith; Zhang, Chenxi; Cheng, Lanxia; Wang, Qingxiao; Lu, Ning; Kim, Moon J.; Kim, Jiyoung; Cho, Kyeongjae; Addou, Rafik; Hinkle, Christopher L.; Appenzeller, Joerg; Wallace, Robert M.

(

5437-5443
CODEN:
NALEFD
; ISSN:
1530-6984
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Controllable doping of two-dimensional materials is highly desired for ideal device performance in both hetero- and p-n homojunctions. Herein, an effective strategy for doping of MoS2 with nitrogen through a remote N2 plasma surface treatment is proposed. By monitoring the surface chem. of MoS2 upon N2 plasma exposure using in situ XPS, the presence of covalently bonded nitrogen in MoS2 is identified, where substitution of the chalcogen sulfur by nitrogen is detd. as the doping mechanism. Furthermore, the elec. characterization demonstrates that p-type doping of MoS2 is achieved by nitrogen doping, which is in agreement with theor. predictions. Notably, it is found that the presence of nitrogen can induce compressive strain in the MoS2 structure, which represents the first evidence of strain induced by substitutional doping in a transition metal dichalcogenide material. Finally, first principle calcns. support the exptl. demonstration of such strain, and a correlation between nitrogen doping concn. and compressive strain in MoS2 is elucidated.

Strain-controlled boron and nitrogen doping of amorphous carbon layers for hard mask applications
Kim, Tae-Wan; Kim, Dongbin; Kim, Yong-Sung; Park, Sang Hyun; Lim, Sung Kyu; Park, Keun Oh.; Kim, Taesung; Kang, Sang-Woo

Nitrogen- and boron-doped amorphous carbon layers (ACLs) were grown by plasma-enhanced chem. vapor deposition (PECVD) on a Si substrate and characterized by Raman and XPS techniques. Increasing doping levels resulted in a shift in the Raman G-peak of the doped ALCs, indicating a change in bond lengths upon doping. The XPS N1s and B1s spectra revealed the presence of different types of N-related (involving pyridinic, pyrrolinic, and graphitic N) and B-related (corresponding to BC2O and B-C species) bonds in the N- and B-doped ACLs, with N and B doping levels ranging from 2.03 to 3.94 at.% and from 1.44 to 10.4 at.%, resp. These results suggest that the dry etch resistance of the present ACLs was enhanced by B doping and neg. affected by N doping. D. functional theory calcns. highlighted the strengthening of C-C bonds induced by B doping and their corresponding weakening caused by N doping as possible explanations for the effects of doping on the dry etching characteristics of the ACLs.

Understanding mechanisms of carbon dioxide conversion into methane for designing enhanced catalysts from first-principles
Shin, Dong Yun; Jo, Jun Ho; Lee, Jai-Young; Lim, Dong-Hee
Computational & Theoretical Chemistry
(
2016
),

(
),
31-37
CODEN:
CTCOA5

2210-271X
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
